children.name: to give sth to sb without expecting to be paid for it
pass
children.definition: to give sth to sb by putting it in their hand or putting it near them,especially because they cannot reach it themselves:đưa cho, lấy hộ, đưa giùm
examples: ▪Could you pass the salt, please?

children.name: pass somebody something
examples: ▪ Would you pass me my sweater? It’s on the back of your chair.

children.name: pass something to somebody
examples: ▪ Ellis quickly passed the note to the woman, looking around to check that no one had noticed.

children.name: give
children.definition: cho, gửi, biếu tặng

children.name: give somebody something
examples: ▪ I gave my nieces and nephews $20 each.
▪ Why don’t we give her some flowers for her birthday?
▪ Let me give you some advices.
▪ They gave me this leaflet - it’s really helpful.
▪ Can you give me a ride to the office tomorrow?

children.name: give something to somebody
examples: ▪ Would you give this letter to your uncle when you see him?
▪ Russell was accused of giving secret information to the enemy.

children.name: hand
children.definition: to take sth in your hand and give it to sb by putting it in their hand:đưa cho

children.name: hand somebody something
examples: ▪ The nurse handed me a glass of brown liquid and told me to drink it.
▪ As the delegates entered the room they were each handed a name-badge.

children.name: hand something to somebody
examples: ▪ Would you please hand your ticket to the man at the door.

children.name: let sb have U
children.definition: let sb have to give something to someone, especially something that they have asked for or something that they need :
examples: She lets her kids have anything they want.
One of my mum’s friends was getting a new sofa, and so she let us have the old one.
If you could let me have your suggestions, it would be very helpful.

children.name: give away
children.definition: to give sth that you own to sb else, especially because youdo not want itor need it:cho đi
examples: ▪ I gave away most of my old furniture because I didn’t have room for it in my new apartment.
▪ He decided to give all his money away and become a Buddhist monk.

children.name: give sth away to sb
examples: ▪ I don’t need all this stuff - I’ll give it away to the first person who asks for it.

children.name: slip
children.definition: to quickly give sb sth small such as money or a piece of paper, by putting it into their hand, especially so that other people do not notice:đút vào, đút lén

children.name: slip sb sth
examples: ▪ I know it’s a private party, but if you slip the doorman $5, he’ll let you in.

children.name: slip sth into sb’s hand/pocket etc
examples: ▪ During the meeting, she reached under the table and slipped a note into my hand.

children.name: spare
children.definition: if you can spare a particular amount of sth, you can only give that amount but no more because you need the rest for yourself: cho
examples: ▪ If anyone can spare a couple of hours a week to help out, it would be much appreciated.
▪ Dad, can you spare a fiver?

children.name: spare somebody something▪ We don’t have very much coffee, I’m afraid, but we can spare you a little
to give sth to each person in a group
pass around
children.definition: alsopass roundUK  if a group of people pass something around, one person takes it and gives it to the next person, who then gives it to the next person:truyền tay nhau
examples: They passed around a list, and we each had to sign our name.
Don’t keep all the chocolates to yourself - pass them around!

children.name: give out
children.definition: /hand outB1  to give sth to all the people in a group:phân phát
examples: ▪ The princess plans to hand out gifts at a children’s hospital tomorrow.
▪ Don’t start the test until I’ve finished giving out the question papers.
▪ I need some volunteers to hand programs out tonight.
hand/give out something to somebody
▪ Outside the embassy, students were handing out leaflets to everyone who walked past

children.name: distribute
children.definition: to give things out to a large number of people, especially in anorganizedway:phân phối, phân bổ , phân phát
examples: ▪ Aid agencies are calling for local volunteers to help them distribute food and medicine.

children.name: distribute something to somebody
examples: ▪ The Red Cross has started distributing food and blankets to villages in the flood area.

children.name: distribute something among somebody
examples: ▪ Medical supplies have been distributed among families affected by the epidemic.

children.name: hand around
children.definition: / roundUK  to go from person to person offering or politely giving them sth such as a drink, food, etc: đi mời, phục vụ
examples: Dorothy was handing around coffee and biscuits when we arrived.
I’m handing round a summary of last week’s lecture.
Would you mind helping me hand the crackers around, please?

children.name: dole out
children.definition: dish out/ to give sth, especially food or money, to people who are waiting to receive it: phân phát, trao tặng
examples: ▪ They want me to dress up as Santa Claus, and dish out presents at the kids’ Christmas party.
▪ The federal government doles out $58 billion in student grants every year.
▪ Jo, would you dish the ice cream out?

children.name: dish/dole out something to somebody
examples: ▪ Air stewardesses were doling out meals to the passengers.

children.name: share out U
children.definition: share out to divide sth into equal parts and give a part to each person:chia đều cho
examples: As long as they share out the profits fairly, everyone will be happy.
Take these cookies and share them out.

children.name: to give sth to sb who had it before
hand back
children.definition: to give sth back to sb by hand: trả lại
examples: ▪ Here’s the file you want. Please hand it back when you’ve finished with it.
▪ Teachers will hand back student assignments after the vacation.

children.name: hand back to sb
examples: ▪ The official looked at her identity card carefully and then handed it back to her.
▪ She handed back the photograph to him.

children.name: return
children.definition: formal to give sth to the person or organization that owns it, especially after you have borrowed it from them: trả lại
examples: ▪ You must return all your library books before the end of the year.

children.name: return something to somebody
examples: ▪ Your passport will be returned to you when you check out of your hotel.

children.name: return sth to its rightful ownergive sth back to the person who has the right to own it
examples: ▪ Since the end of the war, many of the paintings have been found and returned to their rightful owners.

children.name: give back
children.definition: to give sth to the person who gave it to you: trả lại

children.name: give sth back
examples: ▪ Don’t forget to give my pen back when you’ve finished with it.

children.name: give something back to somebody
examples: ▪ He still hasn’t given that book back to me.

children.name: give somebody something back
examples: ▪ I looked at the letter, then gave her it back.
▪ We’ll have to cancel the show and give the audience their money back.

children.name: restore
children.definition: formal to give sth valuable back to its owner, especially after it has been taken from them: hồi lại cho ai

children.name: restore sth to sb
examples: ▪ In 1905 both Japan and Russia agreed to restore Manchuria to China.

children.name: restore sth to its rightful ownergive sth back to the person who has the right to own it
examples: ▪ After decades of colonial rule, the land was finally restored to its rightful owners.

children.name: to give sth that you have received to sb
pass on
children.definition: to give sth that has been given to you to sb else, especially after you have finished using it : chuyền cho, chuyển cho
examples: There’s only one copy of the leaflet, so when you’ve read it please pass it on.

children.name: pass on to sb
examples: When he gave up playing football, he passed on all his gear to me.

children.name: hand down
children.definition: be handed down if sthis handed down, it is given to a younger person in the same family, for example to a sister or brother, or to a son or daughter :truyền lại (từ anh chị)
examples: be handed down to
▪In most big families, clothes are handed down to younger brothers and sisters.
▪The ring had been handed down to her from her grandmother.
▪traditional shipbuilding skills that have been handed down from generation to generation
be handed down from mother to daughter/from father to son
▪ancient stories handed down from father to son

children.name: to give sb sth that you would prefer to keep
give up
children.definition: cho đi
examples: ▪ Fania was prepared to give up all her jewelry to help her father get out of debt.
▪ Russia is very unlikely to give up its nuclear weapons.
▪ Americans love their cars, and no-one is going to persuade them to give them up.

children.name: let sth go U
children.definition: let sth go to unwillingly give or sell something to someone, for example because they have won it from you or you cannot afford to keep it any longer: buông bỏ, thả đi, cho ra đi
examples: They’ve held the world record for many years, and they’re not going to let it go without a fight.
I’ve nowhere to store all this china, so I’m letting the whole lot go for $50.

children.name: part with
children.definition: sth to unwillingly give or sell sth that is very important to you: xa lìa, rời ra, tách ra
examples: ▪ I’m reluctant to part with any of my precious books.
▪ The new house was much smaller, and we had to part with things that we had been hoarding for years.

children.name: sacrifice
children.definition: to agree or decide to stop having sth that is valuable, especially in order to gain sth more important: “hy sinh”

children.name: sacrifice something to do something
examples: He sacrificed a promising career to look after his handicapped daughter.

children.name: sacrifice something for something
examples: The nation is not prepared to sacrifice its independence for the sake of an alliance with a powerful neighbour.

children.name: trade away U
children.definition: trade away to let sb take a right, advantage etc from you - use this when you think sb is stupid to do this: đánh đổi

children.name: trade away something
examples: It’s disgusting to trade away your democratic rights in this way.

children.name: trade away something forlose one thing and gain another
examples: The Unions would be wrong to trade away their future for short-term financial gain.

children.name: be generous
children.definition: We’ve received thousands of dollars to help the children -- people have been incrediblygenerous.

children.name: be generous to
examples: He was very generous to her when they divorced, and let her keep the house and the car.

children.name: be generous with sthgive a lot of something
examples: When it comes to training, Marion’s always been generous with her time.

children.name: lavish
children.definition: sthon sblavish gifts/attention/affection etc onsbto give a lot of gifts, attention etc to someone, especially in an uncontrolled or wasteful way: “hậu hĩnh”
examples: When the series was first shown, the media lavished praise on its creator David Lynch.
Pet owners lavish love and attention on animals because they’re a lot easier to deal with than their fellow human beings.

children.name: shower
children.definition: to give sb a lot of gifts, love, prizes etc: gửi, trao tới tấp

children.name: shower sb with gifts/affection/praise etc
examples: ▪ Trudi was treated as a special guest and was showered with gifts everywhere she went.
▪ His family loved him so much they showered him with affection.

children.name: shower something on/upon somebody
examples: ▪ When Elvis first became famous he had honours and awards showered upon him.

children.name: to give sth extra when sb buys sth
give away
children.definition: if a company gives away sth, they give it to people when they buy the company’s products: tặng kèm
examples: They’re giving away free wine glasses when you spend more than $15 on gas.
700 concert tickets were given away to people buying CDs or cassettes.
give away with sth
‘Where did you get that badge?’ ‘They’re giving them away with this week’s Melody Maker magazine.’

children.name: throw in
children.definition: to give sb sth at no additional cost when they buy something from you: tặng kèm
examples: The person selling the house may offer to throw in the carpets and curtains as part of the deal.
Never mind the chairs -- I’ll throw them in with the table.

children.name: free gift
children.definition: sth, usually something not very valuable, that is given to you when you buy sth else:
examples: Most banks offer students a free gift when they open a new account.
Your Free Gift From Cachet. A perfume atomiser with every 50ml Eau de Toilette purchase.

children.name: to give sb sth useless or that you do not want
palm off
children.definition: palm sth off on sb informal to get rid of sth that you do not want by giving or selling it to sb else without telling them about its faults: tống khứ, đùn đẩy
examples: If he tries to palm that old Ford of his off on you, just tell him you’re not interested.
I’ve managed to palm that early morning class off on Mary - she’s desperate for work.

children.name: offload
children.definition: to get rid of sth such as work or responsibility that you have by giving part of it to sb else: giảm tải. trút bớt
examples: You should try and offload some of your duties and relax more, instead of spending all day at the office.
The bank are trying to offload some of their US holdings.

children.name: fob off
children.definition: fob sb off with sth to make sb accept sth that is not as good as or not the same as the thing that they actually wanted:
examples: Don’t let him fob you off with some cheap imported whisky -- you want the real thing.
People are much more selective about what they watch on TV these days, and they don’t want to be fobbed off with any old rubbish.

children.name: here you are
children.definition: here (you are)used when giving something to someone

children.name: "Could you pass the sugar, please?" "Here you are."
examples: Here, try some of this - it's delicious!

children.name: there you are
children.definition: (informalthere you go) used when giving something to someone, usually after a request for the thing, such as giving sb goods that they have bought

children.name: deliver
children.definition: verbGIVE(deliver something to somebody / something) phân phát; giao; chuyển

children.name: render
children.definition: verbGIVE
examples: formalto give something such as a service, a personal opinion
or expression, or aperformance of a song or poem, etc. to people
_The singers rendered the song with enthusiasm.
_We see that freight railroads make good profits while rendering excellentservice.

children.name: pay
children.definition: verbpaid,paidGIVE
